Course Section: BIOC_V 430-A_201 - Advanced Topics in Protein Biochemistry (A)

Course Section Definition Public Notes: For those who have confirmed a faculty supervisor and want to register into BIOC448, please contact Dr. Lindsay Rogers  lindsay.rogers@ubc.ca.

Biology Laboratory Courses: In most of the Biology Laboratory selections courses (i.e. BIOL 306, 326, 331, 337, 340, 341, 351, 352, 363, 402, 403, 404, and 437, etc.) half of the seats are reserved for 3rd-year Biology students and half of the seats are reserved for 4th-year biology students. Priority will be given to 4th-year Biology students on the waitlist who need a 2nd lab course to graduate if any seats become available in the lab courses after the 3rd-year Biology students have registered. Biology students can only complete or be registered in two biology laboratory courses or waitlists.  Non-biology students interested in taking these courses are to register themselves on the waitlist. They will be considered after all biology students are successfully registered for the course from the waitlist.   

Students may only register for one required course activity per lecture/lab/discussion or waitlist if there is no space available. Students will be removed from the waitlist if they already have a spot in a section of the course.  For example, students may not register for multiple labs or discussions, including their respective waitlists.  BEING ON THE WAITLIST DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU A SPACE IN THE LECTURE, LAB, OR DISCUSSION.

Course Title: Introduction to Natural History Collections & Biodiversity Science

Description: Introduction to Natural History Collections & Biodiversity Science is a brand-new undergraduate course that introduces students to specimen-based science and features UBC’s own Beaty Biodiversity Museum. The course will include a combination of weekly lectures and labs, as well as a major creative project and Beaty Museum Skills Passport. By the end of the course, students will have a foundation in biodiversity science, how biological diversity is preserved in natural history collections, and how those collections are used in scientific research. Along the way, we will explore the historical and contemporary roles of natural history collections in science and society and feature the people behind the collections.

If you are interested in taking this course and are a non-life science student please email bridgette.clarkston@botany.ubc.ca.

Pre-requisites for this pilot course are: SBME undergraduate students: BIOC 202 and BMEG 371, Other UBC undergraduate students: CHBE 381 or similar.

Students without the pre-requisites will be dropped before the course starts.

This course is designed for fourth year students, who have taken BMEG 310, and BMEG 321, which are required pre-requisites. BMEG 350 is strongly recommended but not required.

Students without the pre-requisites will be dropped before the course starts.
